prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 3 Nova
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
This is the Band 3 Science Goal.
Each science goal is aimed at a single epoch. It should be repeated at 4, 8, 12, 28, 46, 78, 110, and 142 days after the first observations, which we call observation zero.

prj:VisitConstraint.prj:note:
The observations are time constrained at 4-8-24-40-72-104-136 days after the start (Visit 1).
Visit 1 should take place within 14 days after trigger, with an error of 2 days.

The observations are time constrained at 4-8-24-40-72-104-136 days after the start (Visit 1).
Visit 1 should take place within 14 days after trigger, with an error of 2 days.

The observations are time constrained at 4-8-24-40-72-104-136 days after the start (Visit 1).
Visit 1 should take place within 14 days after trigger, with an error of 2 days.

The observations are time constrained at 4-8-24-40-72-104-136 days after the start (Visit 1).
Visit 1 should take place within 14 days after trigger, with an error of 2 days.

The observations are time constrained at 4-8-24-40-72-104-136 days after the start (Visit 1).
Visit 1 should take place within 14 days after trigger, with an error of 2 days.

The observations are time constrained at 4-8-24-40-72-104-136 days after the start (Visit 1).
Visit 1 should take place within 14 days after trigger, with an error of 2 days.

The observations are time constrained at 4-8-24-40-72-104-136 days after the start (Visit 1).
Visit 1 should take place within 14 days after trigger, with an error of 2 days.

The observations are time constrained at 4-8-24-40-72-104-136 days after the start (Visit 1).
Visit 1 should take place within 14 days after trigger, with an error of 2 days.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Correlator configuration follows the best TDM continuum setup at Band 3, as given by the OT.

We aim to observe relativistic material, most likely moving at 0.1 the speed of light. At 1 kpc we should observe material moving at 20 mas/day (if on the plane of the sky). The requested angular resolution should decouple this material from the bulk of ejected material (traveling much slower) - otherwise the nova is close a point source early on. Even though structure is expected at later stages of the explosion, but it is unknown exactly how large this will be. At late epochs the nova might still be a point source. Better resolution than 1 arcsecond is encouraged, but not required.

The main goal of this science goal is to resolve relativistic moving material and obtain a relatively accurate flux density measurement. For the earlier epochs, the flux densities are expected to be in the range of 0.1 - 1 mJy while later increasing to 1 - 10 Jy. With the shortest scan time of 2 minutes, a theoretical RMS of 0.07 mJy is reached. However, due to the source brightness at later epochs, we will be dynamic range limited. For this a dynamic range of 1 in 1,000 or better is encouraged. A minimum dynamic range of 1 in 100 is required.
The overheads may be reduced by sharing calibrators for bandpass and gain.

These observations are time critical. The initial 3 visits should be, ideally, within the first 20 days from trigger to allow comparison with the gamma-ray emission. A pattern of 4-8-24-40-72-104-136 days repeat after the start (Visit 1). The error on the days is less than 50% of the interval. It is more important to attempt to get all three bands on the same day than to skip a Band (probably Band 6) due to weather constraints. However, if the weather only allows Bands 3 and/or 4 for a given epoch, these should still be obtained.

We aim to observe relativistic material, most likely moving at 0.1 the speed of light. At 1 kpc we should observe material moving at 20 mas/day (if on the plane of the sky). The requested angular resolution should decouple this material from the bulk of ejected material (traveling much slower) - otherwise the nova is close a point source early on. Better resolution than 1 arcsecond is encouraged, but not required.

The main goal of this science goal is to resolve relativistic moving material and obtain a relatively accurate flux density measurement. For the earlier epochs, the flux densities are expected to be in the range of 0.1 - 1 mJy while later increasing to 1 - 10 Jy. With the shortest scan time of 2 minutes, a theoretical RMS of 0.09 mJy is reached. However, due to the source brightness at later epochs, we will be dynamic range limited. For this a dynamic range of 1 in 1,000 or better is encouraged. A minimum dynamic range of 1 in 100 is required.
The overheads may be reduced by sharing calibrators for bandpass and gain.

These observations are time critical. The initial 3 visits should be, ideally, within the first 20 days from trigger to allow comparison with the gamma-ray emission. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Gamma-ray emission from nova eruptions came as a complete surprise to the community. The nova eruption was not thought to be high velocity particle accelerators. One scenario suggested that the interaction of the ejecta with the secondary's star orbit set up a system of inter-ejecta shocks which was observed as synchrotron emission at the radio frequencies. Novae at the (sub-)mm range are bright allowing us to take advantage of the sensitivity and resolution offered by ALMA in order to: 1) spatially resolve the bulk of the ejecta much earlier allowing us to observe through the ejecta as it becomes optically thin; and 2) probe the source of GeV gamma-ray emission. The former will allow us to observe the effects following the common-envelope phase. We request triggered observations on bands 3, 4, and 6 with a sensitivity of 0.1 mJy RMS over 8 epochs for 1 Fermi detected gamma-ray nova, of which the first 3 epoch are within 20 days of trigger to be simultaneous within the GeV gamma-ray observations. We therefore request a total time of 9.3 hours.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Research Institute for Mathematics, Astrophysics and Particle Physics (IMAPP), Radboud University Nijmegen
